namespace.name: Remotion.ExtensibleEnums
namespace.para: The Remotion.ExtensibleEnums namespace contains an extensible enum infrastructure. Extensible enums are types that enumerate values, similar to ordinary enums, but can be extended to hold new values from the outside. This means an extensible enum declaration is never "finished", every application component can add new values.

Each enum value is uniquely identified by an string formed from a and a string. The base class provides a number of different constructors to define those strings. Each extensible enum type should choose one way to form the identifier and expose only one constructor conforming to that way.

There can be more than one extension class defining values for an extensible enum type, and the values can even be defined in different assemblies. The extensible enum infrastructure uses the to find all the values defined for an extensible enum type. This means that, by default, all application assemblies in the application directory are analyzed to find extensible enum values. This behavior can be customized by configuring the .

Apart from serving as the declaration target of the extension methods defining extensible enum values, the class also provides a way to reflectively look up all values of a given extensible enum type and to retrieve a single value by its . Instances of can be retrieved via the (strongly types) or (in reflective scenarios).

It is possible to derive classes from an extensible enum type and override methods in those subclasses. Values for the enum type must still be defined via extension methods for , where T is the base enum type, not the derived one, but the extension methods can return instances of the derived classes.

To attach resources to extensible enum values, apply the to the class declaring the extension methods which define the values. The resource identifiers in the corresponding resource file must equal the enum values' IDs.
